answer_html: Also by Rank-Nullity theorem: dim(N(DT)) = n - r(D) = 7 - 5 = 2 and hence these two loop current vectors form a basis in N(DT) and any other loop current can be expressed using a linear combination of these two basis vectors.
answer_latex:
Also by Rank-Nullity theorem:
\emph{dim(N(D\textsuperscript{T})) = n - r(D) = 7 - 5 = 2} and hence
these two loop current vectors form a basis in
\emph{N(D\textsuperscript{T})} and any other loop current can be
expressed using a linear combination of these two basis vectors.
question: Section 201 05 (b)
sols_html:
Reading off graph (using -1 indicated opposite direction as shown, +1 to indicate same direction as shown) (each row corresponds to an edge)

\[\begin{aligned} \vec{v_1} = \begin{bmatrix} 1\\0\\-1\\1\\0\\-1\\0 \end{bmatrix}, \vec{v_2} = \begin{bmatrix} 0\\-1\\0\\1\\-1\\0\\1 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

These form a complete basis in N(DT) if the dim(N(DT)) = 2. So (if D has n rows and m columns): dim(N(D)) = 1 (# of connected circuits). Therefore, r(D) = m - dim(N(D)) = 6 - 1 = 5 (by Rank-Nullity theorem). Also by Rank-Nullity theorem: dim(N(DT)) = n - r(D) = 7 - 5 = 2 and hence these two loop current vectors form a basis in N(DT) and any other loop current can be expressed using a linear combination of these two basis vectors.
statement_html:
Consider the following graph, interpreted as a resistor network with all resistances R = 1.

(b) Write down 2 independent loop vectors. Is any other loop vector a linear combination of these? Give a reason.
statement_raw:
Consider the following graph, interpreted as a resistor network with all resistances ''R = 1''.

:[[File:MATH307April2013Section201Q5a.png|300px]]

'''(b)''' Write down 2 independent loop vectors. Is any other loop vector a linear combination of these? Give a reason.
